config.text: The NRE tracks 43 conviction type categories. Some categories have been combined to make the charts easier to read.

• Child Abuse includes Child Abuse and Child Sex Abuse categories.
  • Other Nonviolent includes Bribery, Conspiracy, Dependent Adult Abuse, Destruction of Property, Failure to Pay Child Support, Filing a False Report, Forgery, Fraud, Harassment, Immigration, Military Justice Offense, Obstruction of Justice, Official Misconduct, Other Nonviolent Felony, Other Nonviolent Misdemeanor, Perjury, Possession of Stolen Property, Solicitation, Stalking, Supporting Terrorism, Tax Evasion/Fraud, Theft, Traffic Offense, and Weapons Possession or Sale categories.
  • Other Violent includes Accessory to Murder, Attempted Murder, Attempted Violence, Kidnapping, Manslaughter, Menacing, Other Violent Felony, Other Violent Misdemeanor, and Threats categories.
  • Robbery includes Burglary/Unlawful Entry and Robbery categories.
  • Sexual Assault includes Sexual Assault and Sex Offender Registration categories.
The NRE tracks six racial type categories.

config.text: The Innocence Project, founded in 1992 by Peter Neufeld and Barry Scheck at Cardozo School of Law, exonerates the wrongly convicted through DNA testing. The Innocence Project's mission is to free the staggering number of innocent people who remain incarcerated, and to bring reform to the system responsible for their unjust imprisonment.
THE AMERICAN CRIMINAL JUSTICE SYSTEM AT A GLANCE

The National Registry of Exonerations is a project of the Newkirk Center for Science & Society at University of California Irvine, the University of Michigan Law School and Michigan State University College of Law. It was founded in 2012 in conjunction with the Center on Wrongful Convictions at Northwestern University School of Law. The Registry provides detailed information about every known exoneration in the United States since 1989—cases in which a person was wrongly convicted of a crime and later cleared of all the charges based on new evidence of innocence.

Welcome!

﻿This application is part of a university project for educational use and is not a collaboration with any of the organizations mentioned. Use of names, logos and data are for informative purposes only.


Please feel free to use the site to learn more about issues in the American criminal justice system. We recommend you visit the Innocence Project, the National Registry of Exonerations, or other organizations seeking to improve the justice systems and those wrongfully imprisoned.
